since_last_update: US macro impulse flipped firmer: durable goods orders beat with a large headline rebound (+5.3%) and a positive core print, reinforcing a “growth not rolling over” read into the Fed window; this typically pushes yields/real yields up and is a headwind to long-duration equity factor leadership (Durable goods release; Investing.com, Reuters via Investing.com).

Europe growth tone modestly softened: Germany’s Ifo business climate missed expectations and was flat m/m (87.6 vs ~88.2 est), reinforcing a “no momentum” narrative that can marginally support core Europe rates and weigh on EUR; spillover to US risk is second-order unless it coincides with a broader global risk-off tape (Reuters via Investing.com).

Policy-risk bid in havens strengthened: trade-policy escalation rhetoric (Trump tariff threat vs Canada) and renewed US shutdown brinkmanship headlines are being cited alongside the Fed/earnings calendar as drivers of cautious risk positioning; gold’s safe-haven impulse is particularly visible (MarketWatch; AP; Barron’s).

Market narrative broadened from pure macro to event-risk clustering: this week stacks FOMC + mega-cap earnings, increasing convexity/gap risk for ES/NQ even without a single dominant data release beyond durables (MarketWatch; Barron’s).
today_focus: Dominant driver check: event-risk + policy uncertainty is competing with a rates repricing impulse. Net: the market’s “what matters today” looks like (1) FOMC/mega-cap earnings risk premia and (2) trade/shutdown headlines—both supportive of gold demand and a more cautious equity-futures tone (MarketWatch; Barron’s; AP).

Rates channel: the durable-goods upside surprise raises the odds that the Fed stays firm and that real yields remain a pressure point for Nasdaq-duration; watch whether the equity tape treats the data as ‘good growth’ (cyclicals) or ‘bad rates’ (duration) (Reuters via Investing.com; Investing.com).

Gold: safe-haven bid appears headline-led (tariffs/shutdown/geopolitics) rather than purely USD/real-rate driven, implying correlation instability vs equities and rates intraday (MarketWatch; AP; Barron’s).

Microstructure/positioning: with multiple binary catalysts, expect higher sensitivity to intraday headlines and guidance leaks; index-level moves may be driven by a narrow set of mega-caps, increasing ES vs NQ divergence risk (MarketWatch; Barron’s).

market_pricing.dominant_narrative: Event-risk clustering (FOMC + mega-cap earnings) layered with policy uncertainty (tariffs/shutdown) is the primary macro-risk premium input; durable-goods strength adds a secondary rates-up impulse that can weigh on equity duration while supporting cyclicals.

what_is_priced: Higher near-term event-risk premium into FOMC and major tech earnings; reduced tolerance for negative guidance surprises.
Greater sensitivity to rates/real-yield moves after firmer US activity data (durables), skewing factor performance (value/cyclicals vs duration).
underpriced_risks: Gap risk from trade/shutdown headlines that reprice inflation expectations and front-end rates simultaneously (risk-off + rates-up mix).
Single-name mega-cap guidance shocks propagating to index futures (NQ beta concentration).

rates.bias: upward pressure on yields / tighter financial-conditions impulse
what_is_priced: Durables beat reinforces a ‘Fed hold’ baseline and reduces urgency for near-term easing; market likely keeps a higher bar for dovish repricing into FOMC (Reuters via Investing.com).
underpriced_risks: Nonlinear reaction function risk: if the Fed stresses inflation vigilance despite mixed inflation prints, real yields could reprice higher quickly, hitting duration and supporting USD (uncertain; driver depends on FOMC messaging).

what_is_priced: USD direction may be torn between risk-off demand (supports USD) and policy-credibility/shutdown concerns (can weaken USD), increasing cross-asset correlation uncertainty (MarketWatch; AP).
underpriced_risks: Headline-driven USD swings that spill into gold and Nasdaq via financial conditions.

what_is_priced: Safe-haven demand tied to tariffs/shutdown/geopolitics is being actively priced, keeping gold responsive to political headlines even if rates rise (MarketWatch; AP; Barron’s).
underpriced_risks: Sharp whipsaw if rates/real yields gap higher post-data/Fed while geopolitical risk fades intraday; correlation with equities may flip quickly.

risk_register.risk: Policy shock: Trump tariff escalation vs Canada (and broader trade spillover) reignites inflation-risk premium and risk-off simultaneously (worst case: equities down while yields up).
US government funding/shutdown brinkmanship into the Jan 30 deadline creates headline gap risk and safe-haven flows; could distort USD/gold correlations.

FOMC communication risk: a ‘hawkish hold’ tone after firm activity data lifts real yields and pressures Nasdaq-duration; alternatively a dovish surprise can reflate duration but may amplify USD/gold volatility.
risk_register.timeframe: FOMC week (Wed/Thu depending on statement/PC timing)

risk_register.risk: Mega-cap earnings/guidance concentration: index moves dominated by a few names; NQ vs ES divergence and post-close gap risk.
Europe growth softness becomes a broader global-growth catalyst (Ifo miss as an early hint); could reinforce defensive factor moves if PMIs confirm.

event_warnings: US durable goods (released today) printed much stronger than expected, increasing odds of a rates-led equity rotation rather than broad risk-on (Reuters via Investing.com; Investing.com).

US data cluster Tuesday: Case-Shiller/house prices, Consumer Confidence, Richmond Fed—watch for confirmation/contradiction of the ‘firm demand’ read from durables and resulting front-end rate sensitivity (calendar).
FOMC rate decision/statement + press conference late week: messaging risk is the primary macro catalyst for rates, USD, and equity duration (calendar; MarketWatch).
Government funding deadline Friday Jan 30, 2026: shutdown headlines can hit late-day liquidity and create weekend gap risk if unresolved (Time; AP).
Ongoing trade-policy headlines (tariff threats) are directly feeding safe-haven demand; gold may remain headline-driven even if rates rise (MarketWatch; AP; Barron’s).
